headline.main: Growing Old, With the Bones in One Piece

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on osteoporosis, how to protect oneself against it and drugs that foster healthy bone growth; says habits of young Americans today portend future epidemic of osteoporosis that far exceeds today's problems; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bones, once taken for granted, have become a major health issue now that so many Americans are living well into their 70's, 80's and beyond. For at least half of women and one in eight men, bones are not bearing up as well as they should to sustain an active, independent old age free of debilitating fractures. As a result, osteoporosis -- bones seriously weakened by mineral loss -- has become a household word, as familiar to most people as cholesterol. And the pharmaceutical industry, supplement makers and now food producers have responded with products intended to keep Americans from breaking apart before their time on earth is up.
